Message.Msg: The warehouse distribution I may have read on Tech in Asia - I don't remember & I can't find it. But, The Next Web is a fairly large well-known international blog. Yes it was the Asian version that reported it, but the detail that is contains should have been picked up on today. They jumped on the fact that AG may not do the IPO on the US exchanges, yet this info they have let float. That may be why the rumor was out that they will IPO in HK. At least one of the IPO's probably will be in HK. But the first up is E-Commerce according to the article & I think that will be done on a US exchange.

FT says Alibaba seeks public listing in Hong Kong as early as Q4 2013, valuation up to $70bn: Financial Times thenextwebDOTcom/asia/2013/05/29/alibaba-seeks-public-listing-in-hong-kong-as-early-as-q4-2013-valuation-up-to-70bn-financial-times/?fromcat=all

I recognize that all of these articles are based on rumors. But, yesterday's article on grouping certain sub-co's together & bringing 3 or more IPO's to market, makes me wonder what the 1st IPO will really be worth. It's been awhile, but last year when they negotiated the purchase of 20% of Yahoo`s stake, did they not get the right to purchase back the remaining stake upon IPO? Is Yahoo forced to sell back? I seem to remember some wording at that time that struck me. Now we have the rumor that they will break up the IPO, so is it possible that the 1st IPO will be say 30 - 40 billion forcing Yahoo! to sell back stock based on really half of what AG is truly worth.

I thought the same thing. The article also says Alipay will be part of an independent IPO for the financial services arm of Alibaba. If you remember they took Alipay away from Alibaba and didn't pay shareholders anything. Sounds like it's coming again. My bet is they will demand Yahoo return their 50% stock holdings for the first of three Alibaba IPO's. Stairstep the valuations of the three IPO's to build value for themselves.
